awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT: Prototyping a Pesticide Detoxifier for High Value Crops
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project will result in a safe and effective way to ensure full detoxification and removal of commonly used pesticides in the protection of several different crops such as wine grapes and tea leaves. Many pesticides cannot be easily removed with water, and, therefore, pose a public health risk as these pesticides persist on the surface of these products. This project will develop a protein-based technology that can break down a particular class of pesticide called organophosphates into two benign products that can be more easily removed with water.  Through this, consumers could more easily enjoy fruits and vegetables protected by this particular class of pesticides. 

The proposed project will result in the collaboration of protein engineers, chemists, and computer scientists. Ultimately, the team plans to develop a single protein designed by computer scientists, produced by protein engineers, and stabilized by chemists. Computer scientists, experts in the design of proteins with improved function, will provide the blueprint for the protein engineers to develop in the lab. The protein engineers will produce the proteins and assess their efficacy with several commonly used pesticides. The chemists will then encapsulate the crystals in a sugar to ensure the products' efficacy following storage of several months. A diverse group of scientists will bring new ideas to solve the problem of pesticide persistence on the surfaces of fruits and vegetables, as well as develop a commercially viable solution for this pervasive problem.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
Organophosphates (OPs) are a class of potent neurotoxins, many of which resist treatment. OPs remain a threat both from intentional poisonings as acts of warfare or attempted assassinations and through accidental exposure to OPs used as insecticides. The enzyme phosphotriesterase (PTE) has been shown to break down some OPs, but further work is needed to both improve the enzyme’s stability and to broaden the range of OPs it is able to break down. Past work from our group has shown that fluorinating PTE can improve its stability while maintaining its enzymatic activity against a common substrate.

            In this project we used computational models to design a series of new variants of the enzyme PTE that we predicted would be more stable and have better activity against VX and VR, two OPs used as chemical weapons. We synthesized six new variants of PTE as well as a previously characterized variant to compare them with. Then we studied the stability, structure, and catalytic efficiency of each variant. We found that all six non-fluorinated variants showed similar structure and melting temperature to the original enzyme, indicating that the computational designs folded correctly and stably. Unusually, the new designs only had a single melting temperature, which suggests that unlike the original PTE enzyme, their two domains dissociate at the same time as they unfold. Three variants showed improved activity against VX and VR relative to the original enzyme. Using this information, we identified two beneficial active site mutations, one harmful active site mutation, and six stabilizing mutations outside of the active site. This knowledge will allow us to create the next generation of organophosphate-degrading enzymes.

            We also used computational models to design a series of PTE variants with highly charged surfaces. We had previously found that adding fluorinated amino acids to PTE could improve its stability, but made it less soluble and prone to aggregation, which cancelled out the helpful effects. We hypothesized that increasing the charge of the enzyme’s surface would make it more stable overall. We designed several variants with charged surfaces and selected two positive and two negative to test. The more highly charged variants (charges of -26 and +20) did not fold properly, but the less charged variants (-14 and +12) did. The positively charged fluorinated variant was not very active, but the negatively charged fluorinated variant showed strong activity that was retained even after heating to near the enzyme’s melting point, which shows that it has improved stability.

            This funding also had impact beyond the research activity. Three postdocs, three PhD students, three MS students, five BS students and two high school students have had the opportunity to be trained through this work. Two postdocs and one PhD student took part in NSF I-Corps training as part of this work, which built their entrepreneurial skills and helped bring a culture of entrepreneurship to our lab. Since then, two other teams from our lab have participated in I-Corps. The feedback we have gotten during I-Corps interviews has proven important in shaping our research direction and making sure that we focus on studying things that solve problems that interviewees have identified. This helps make sure that as scientists and engineers, we are working for the common good.

 

 


Last Modified: 03/25/2023
Modified by: Jin K Montclare
